message_1: A spaceship is moving towards Earth at a velocity of 0.6c. The spaceship emits a 2000 Hz signal towards Earth. What frequency will be detected by an observer on Earth?
message_2:
To solve this problem, we will use the relativistic Doppler effect formula, which takes into account the effects of special relativity. The formula is:

f_observed = f_emitted * sqrt((1 + v/c) / (1 - v/c))

where f_observed is the frequency detected by the observer on Earth, f_emitted is the frequency emitted by the spaceship, v is the velocity of the spaceship relative to the observer, and c is the speed of light.

In this case, f_emitted = 2000 Hz and v = 0.6c. Plugging these values into the formula, we get:

f_observed = 2000 * sqrt((1 + 0.6) / (1 - 0.6))

f_observed = 2000 * sqrt(1.6 / 0.4)

f_observed = 2000 * sqrt(4)

f_observed = 2000 * 2

f_observed = 4000 Hz

So, the frequency detected by an observer on Earth will be 4000 Hz.
